Subject: Discharge Summary for Patient ___, Age: 58, Male  

Dear Dr. ___,

I am writing to provide a summary of the hospital stay for Mr. ___, who was admitted on March 1, 2024, and discharged on March 6, 2024. The patient presented with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and shortness of breath, prompting immediate admission under suspicion of acute coronary syndrome.

Upon admission, Mr. ___ underwent diagnostic evaluations, including an electrocardiogram (ECG), which revealed an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) of the anterior wall. The diagnosis was confirmed as an acute transmural myocardial infarction (I21.0). Subsequently, the patient underwent a successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement, with stable post-procedure status noted.

Throughout the hospitalization, Mr. ___ exhibited progressive clinical improvement. Initial blood tests indicated elevated troponin levels, peaking at 12 hours post-admission. Subsequent measurements showed a decline in troponin levels, reflecting his improving cardiac status. A complete blood count (CBC) was within normal limits, although a lipid profile disclosed elevated LDL cholesterol levels.

Medically, the regimen included Aspirin 325 mg once daily, Clopidogrel 75 mg once daily, and a continuous infusion of IV Heparin as per protocol. Nitroglycerin was administered as needed for recurrent chest pain. From March 2, 2024, additional medications included Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily, Lisinopril 10 mg once daily, and a statin at a dose of 40 mg once daily.

The patient remained stable without recurrent chest pain, and vital signs indicated he was in good spirits throughout recovery. Nursing and medical notes describe effective pain management and no complications, facilitating the planning of discharge and rehabilitation.

Upon discharge, Mr. ___ was provided with instructions for a heart-healthy lifestyle, emphasizing a diet low in saturated fats, cholesterol, and sodium, with increased consumption of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. He was encouraged to reintroduce physical activity gradually, aiming for 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity weekly. Smoking cessation was recommended, with supportive resources provided. Stress management strategies, such as mindfulness or yoga, were suggested for holistic well-being.

A follow-up appointment in the cardiology outpatient clinic is scheduled for March 20, 2024, to monitor recovery progress and manage ongoing treatment.

Please do not hesitate to contact me should you require further details on Mr. ___’s hospital course.

Best regards,

Dr. ___
